ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Take it! I really enjoyed the class. While you may be daunted by the workload (decent amount of reading and 5 papers), Professor Sorkin gives you the opportunity to rewrite your papers, which always improved my grade. You do actually have to do the reading though. I was somewhat nervous coming into the class because I expected to be surrounded by former Jewish day school students, but there was a wide range of experience represented (and an interesting cast of auditors). Some previous knowledge of Jewish history/terms might be helpful but definitely not necessary. Overall it was a great class, and I'd highly recommend it!
Summary: A broad overview of major themes in modern Jewish history, examined through a variety of specific documentary sources. Yes, I would recommend HIST220-01 to another student.

Take this course! Whether you're 100% Jewish or just like to eat Bagel Brunch at Slifka sometimes, this course will totally blow your mind with new insight, every week. A whirlwind introduction to the history of the Jewish people, rooted in close considerations of historical documents. Also, a great balance of coursework, spaced throughout the semester.

I would absolutely recommend this course to a fellow student. I think it would be of particular interest to students of religious studies or other students such as myself, who are Jewish, but do not have a deep background and want to learn more regarding the factors that have strongly influenced modern Jewish history and culture.
Great history class. Interesting classes and readings. 5 short papers. Sorkin's great.
